# PPL Corporation (PPL) - Comprehensive Analysis Report

## 1. Company Overview

PPL Corporation is an energy company headquartered in Allentown, Pennsylvania in the Lehigh Valley region of eastern Pennsylvania. The company is publicly traded on the New York Stock Exchange as NYSE: PPL and is part of the S&P 500. As of 2022, the company had $7.9 billion in revenue, 6,500 employees, over $37 billion in assets, and serves 3.6 million customers. PPL Corp (PPL) is an energy holding company. Through its subsidiaries, LG&E, Kentucky Utilities, and KU Energy, the company generates, transmits, distributes, and sells electricity, and distributes and sells natural gas. It serves residential, commercial, industrial, and other customers in the US.

It operates through three segments: Kentucky Regulated, Pennsylvania Regulated, and Rhode Island Regulated. The company delivers electricity to customers in Pennsylvania, Kentucky, Virginia, and Rhode Island; delivers natural gas to customers in Kentucky and Rhode Island; and generates electricity from power plants in Kentucky. PPL Corporation was founded as Pennsylvania Power & Light in 1920, the product of a merger of eight smaller Pennsylvania-based utility companies.

## 2. Current Market Data

At close: January 2 at 4:00:02 PM EST · 35.01 · -0.12 · (-0.34%) Pre-Market: 9:08:52 AM EST · Market Cap (intraday) 25.972B · Beta (5Y Monthly) 0.72 · PE Ratio (TTM) 23.88 · EPS (TTM) 1.47 · Forward Dividend & Yield 1.09 (3.10%)

**Current Stock Price:** $35.01 (as of January 2, 2026)

**52-Week Range:** $31.22 - $38.27

**Beta:** 0.72
**Dividend Yield:** 3.10%

## 3. Existing Products/Services

PPL operates as a regulated utility company providing essential services across its three segments:

• **Pennsylvania Regulated:** The Pennsylvania Regulated segment consists of the regulated electricity transmission and distribution operations of PPL Electric Utilities Corporation. PPL Electric delivered electricity to approximately 1.5 million customers

• **Kentucky Regulated:** The Kentucky Regulated segment consists of LKE's regulated electricity generation, transmission and distribution operations of Louisville Gas and Electric Company and Kentucky Utilities Company as well as regulated distribution and sale of natural gas of Louisville Gas and Electric Company. Louisville Gas and Electric and Kentucky Utilities, which serves 1.3 million customers in nearly 100 counties across Kentucky and Virginia, has won 28 J.D. Power awards for customer satisfaction.

• **Rhode Island Regulated:** The Rhode Island Regulated segment primarily consists of regulated electricity transmission and distribution operations and regulated distribution and sale of natural gas conducted by RIE. RIE provided electric service to approximately 515,000 customers and natural gas service to approximately 280,000 customers.

## 4. Planned Products/Services/Projects

### Major Infrastructure Investments
In addition, the company increased planned infrastructure investments to $20 billion from 2025 through 2028, compared to the prior plan of $14.3 billion from 2024 to 2027. These investments are expected to result in 9.8% average annual rate base growth through 2028, up from 6.3% over the prior plan period. The company is targeting $4.3 billion in infrastructure investments in 2025.

### Kentucky Generation Projects
LG&E and KU received approval to construct a 640 MW NGCC turbine, a 120 MW solar facility, and a 125 MW battery storage system.

### Data Center Infrastructure
LG&E's new utility partnership with Poe Companies and PowerHouse Data Centers sets stage for Kentucky's first hyperscale data center campus · The joint venture is developing Kentucky's cutting-edge 400-megawatt data center campus which will be located in Louisville. The first 130 megawatts will be available in October 2026.

### Pennsylvania Generation Joint Venture
PPL Corporation and Blackstone Infrastructure created a joint venture to build natural gas generation in Pennsylvania in support of data center development. If all 13 GW come online, PPL estimates a 6 GW generation shortfall in PPL Electric Utilities' service territory in the next five to six years. That represents about a $15 billion investment need, assuming natural gas combined-cycle units are used to meet this need.

## 5. Growth Strategy

PPL's "Utility of the Future" strategy focuses on five key objectives:

• **Grid Reliability & Resilience:** Hardening infrastructure and automating networks to enhance grid resilience and reliability.

• **Data Science & AI:** Leveraging data science to drive efficiency, affordability and improved outcomes for customers.

• **Smart Grid Technology:** Pioneering smart delivery systems to reliably and efficiently integrate widespread renewables.

• **Technology Partnership:** Accenture (NYSE: ACN) and Apptio are working with PPL Corporation, a U.S. energy company providing electricity and natural gas to more than 3.6 million customers in the U.S., to transform how the company prioritizes and manages technology spending. As part of this effort, Accenture is delivering a new technology financial management platform for PPL, powered by Apptio's solutions. This approach automates reporting and provides real-time financial data, enabling the company to make smarter, faster decisions on where and how to invest in technology to advance its strategic objectives.

## 6. Current and Potential Major Clients

### Data Center Clients
PPL Electric Utilities has advanced-stage agreements to interconnect about 14 GW of data centers in its Pennsylvania service territory, up 32% from three months ago, Vincent Sorgi, president and CEO of PPL Corp., said Thursday during an earnings conference call. Under signed agreements, PPL Electric Utilities' data center load could grow from 800 MW in 2026 to 14.4 GW in 2034, according to a second-quarter earnings presentation.

PPL Electric Utilities has a 60-GW data center interconnection queue, according to Sorgi. "The joint venture is actively engaged with hyperscalers, landowners, natural gas pipeline companies and turbine manufacturers and has secured multiple land parcels to enable this new generation buildout," Sorgi said.

### Traditional Customer Base
Louisville Gas and Electric Company and Kentucky Utilities Company, part of the PPL Corporation (NYSE: PPL) family of companies, are regulated utilities that serve more than 1.3 million customers and have consistently ranked among the best companies for customer service in the United States. LG&E serves 335,000 natural gas and 436,000 electric customers in Louisville and 16 surrounding counties. KU serves 545,000 customers in 77 Kentucky counties and 28,000 in five counties in Virginia.

## 7. Financial Data & Performance

### 2024 Financial Results
PPL Corporation (NYSE: PPL) today announced 2024 reported earnings (GAAP) of $888 million, or $1.20 per share, compared with 2023 reported earnings of $740 million, or $1.00 per share. Adjusting for special items, 2024 earnings from ongoing operations (non-GAAP) were $1.25 billion, or $1.69 per share, compared with $1.18 billion, or $1.60 per share, a year ago.

PPL Corp reported strong financial performance for 2024, with significant improvements across key metrics: Operating Revenues: $8,462 million, reflecting a $150 million increase from 2023 primarily due to higher distribution prices and volumes, and increased transmission formula rate returns. Operating Income: $1,740 million, an increase of $110 million from 2023, driven by higher operating revenues and controlled operating expenses.

### Dividend Information
Announces approximately 6% increase in quarterly common stock dividend.

### 2025 Guidance
Extends 6% to 8% annual EPS and dividend growth targets through at least 2028; expects to achieve EPS growth in the top half of targeted growth range.

## 8. Headwinds & Tailwinds

### Tailwinds
• **AI & Data Center Demand:** In the next three years the electricity needed for AI centers will rise to 12% of electricity demand from the current 4%, Kishore said. "The writing's on the wall in terms of the data centers expanding and growing," she said. "There's been a lot of recent studies that show there's going to be a significant growth of the number of data centers, and what it means for the sort of electricity consumption of them.

• **Regulatory Support:** The long period without a rate increase is attributed to the constructive regulatory framework in Pennsylvania and PPL's focus on efficiency and affordability, which has led to significant reliability improvements and capabilities, such as rapid connection of large load customers like data centers.

• **Strategic Location:** Shalinee Kishore, director of Lehigh University's Center for Advancing Community Electrification Solutions, said such deals are natural for Pennsylvania — with its natural gas supply, it is one of the top states for energy exports.

### Headwinds
• **Generation Capacity Shortfalls:** PJM Interconnection has forecasted the potential for capacity shortages as early as the 2026-27 delivery year. With surging demand from data centers, increasing retirements of aging dispatchable generation, and the vast majority of resources in PJM's interconnection queue being intermittent with historically low completion rates, new solutions are needed now.

• **Regulatory Risks:** The company's operations are subject to extensive federal and state regulations, which could lead to increased costs or operational changes. Changes in environmental regulations, particularly those affecting coal-fired generation, could result in significant compliance costs.

• **High Capital Requirements:** Given the significant increase in capital needs in its updated business plan, PPL projects equity needs of $2.5 billion over the plan period to support this growth.

## 9. Market Shares

The company reported $8.5 billion in revenue and $41 billion in assets as of December 31, 2024, serving over 3.6 million customers. PPL operates as a regulated monopoly within its defined service territories, providing stable market positions in:

• **Pennsylvania:** Approximately 1.5 million electric customers
• **Kentucky:** 1.3 million customers (electric and gas combined)
• **Rhode Island:** 515,000 electric customers and 280,000 gas customers

The company's market share within its regulated territories approaches 100% as a monopoly utility provider, with growth potential primarily driven by customer additions and load growth.

## 10. Comparison to Competitors

The main competitors of PPL Corporation in 2024 include Duke Energy Corporation, NextEra Energy, Inc., Exelon Corporation, Southern Company, and American Electric Power (AEP). In the competitive landscape of 2024, PPL faces competition from major utility companies such as Duke Energy, NextEra Energy, Exelon Corporation, Southern Company, and American Electric Power. These companies are significant players in the utility sector, with strong market positions and a focus on renewable energy and technological advancements.

**Key Competitive Advantages:**
• The company operates as a regulated monopoly in its service areas, ensuring stable revenue streams and a predictable return on investment, which is a key differentiator in the energy sector.
• Strong customer satisfaction ratings with multiple J.D. Power awards
• Advanced positioning in the data center market with significant pipeline
• Strategic location in Pennsylvania with access to natural gas resources

## 11. Partnerships, Mergers and Acquisitions

### Strategic Joint Venture
Pennsylvania is competing again, and it is clear that with the significant investments recently announced in the commonwealth and today's historic announcement by PPL and Blackstone Infrastructure, Pennsylvania is primed for investments in energy, data centers, AI and more. "And in Blackstone Infrastructure, we've found a tremendous partner and long-term energy infrastructure investor that not only has deep expertise in data center development and power generation but also shares our passion to deliver America's AI dominance and to help address resource adequacy concerns within PJM."

### Technology Partnership
"Our recent work with Accenture is another step in our strategy to create the technology-enabled utilities of the future," said Dean Del Vecchio, Executive Vice President—Technology and Innovation for PPL.

### Recent Acquisitions
This resulted in a March 18, 2021, announcement of agreements to sell WPD to National Grid plc for £7.8 billion and acquire National Grid's Rhode Island electric and gas utility, the Narragansett Electric Company, for $3.8 billion. The sale of WPD was completed on June 14, 2021. The sale of the Narragansett Electric Company was completed on May 25, 2022, and Narragansett Electric was renamed Rhode Island Energy.

## 12. Recent Developments

### Headquarters Relocation (March 1, 2024)
On March 1, 2024, PPL Corporation announced that its subsidiary PPL Electric Utilities reached a tentative $9 million agreement to sell its 2 North Ninth St. Tower Building and office complex to Pennsylvania-based developer D&D Realty Group.

### Financial Performance (February 13, 2025)
PPL Corporation reports 2024 earnings results; updates business plan and extends growth targets through 2028 · Announces 2024 reported earnings (GAAP) of $1.20 per share. Achieves earnings from ongoing operations of $1.69 per share.

### Data Center Expansion
As of late July, PPL reported nearly 14 gigawatts of advanced-stage interconnection requests, a 32 percent increase from earlier this year. These projects are primarily driven by large-scale data center operators, many of which are supporting artificial intelligence and cloud computing applications.

### Rate Case Filings
PPL Electric Utilities expects to file a base rate case by the end of 2025, its first in a decade. This filing will support continued grid strengthening against storms and the integration of advanced technologies.

## 13. AI Investment Rating & Fair Value Assessment

### Clean Energy Commitment
PPL has set an ambitious goal to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. In addition, we are targeting a 70% reduction from 2010 levels by 2035 and an 80% reduction by 2040. We continue to make progress toward our goal, and we are on track to achieve our interim targets.

### Investment Strengths
• Strong positioning in the high-growth data center market with 14 GW pipeline
• Regulated utility model providing stable cash flows and predictable returns
• Strategic partnership with Blackstone Infrastructure for generation development
• Robust capital investment program of $20 billion through 2028
• Strong regulatory relationships and constructive rate recovery mechanisms
• Commitment to clean energy transition with clear net-zero targets by 2050

### Risk Factors
• High capital requirements and equity needs of $2.5 billion through plan period
• Exposure to coal generation requiring significant transition investments
• Regulatory risks in multiple jurisdictions
• Capacity constraints in PJM market requiring new generation investments

### Financial Metrics Analysis
Based on current financial performance and growth prospects:
• P/E Ratio of 23.88 indicates reasonable valuation for utility sector
• 6-8% projected annual EPS growth through 2028
• Strong dividend yield of 3.10% with 6% quarterly increase announced
• Solid balance sheet supporting investment-grade credit ratings

**Buy Rating: 7.8/10**

This rating reflects PPL's strong positioning in the growing data center market, stable regulated utility business model, and clear growth strategy, balanced against execution risks associated with large capital investments and the clean energy transition.

**Estimated Fair Value: $42.50**

Based on projected EPS growth, dividend growth trajectory, comparable utility valuations, and the significant data center growth opportunity, the fair value represents approximately 21% upside from current levels. This valuation assumes successful execution of the capital investment program and realization of data center growth opportunities while maintaining regulatory support and manageable financing costs.
tldr_summary:
PPL Corporation is a regulated utility company serving 3.6 million customers across Pennsylvania, Kentucky, and Rhode Island, generating electricity and distributing natural gas through its subsidiaries. The company is strategically positioning itself for future growth by aggressively expanding into the high-demand data center market, with a $20 billion infrastructure investment plan through 2028 and a 14 GW data center interconnection pipeline driven by AI and cloud computing needs. Key strategic advantages include a monopoly utility model, strong regulatory relationships, and partnerships with Blackstone Infrastructure and Accenture to enhance technology infrastructure. The company is committed to a clean energy transition with net-zero carbon emissions targeted by 2050 and demonstrates financial stability with consistent EPS and dividend growth. Potential risks include substantial capital requirements and regulatory complexities in the energy sector.

The AI analysis assigns a 7.8/10 buy rating with a fair value of $42.50, reflecting strong market positioning and growth potential, representing approximately 21% upside from current stock prices.
